STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 18, 2019
Steven Zwart
Wellspring Lutheran Services Oak Park
25900 Greenfield Suit 401
Oak Park, MI 48237
RE: License #: CB630201261
Wellspring Lutheran Services Oak Park
25900 Greenfield Suit 401
Oak Park, MI 48237
Dear Mr. Zwart:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
04/05/2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Licensee #: CB630201261
Licensee Name: Wellspring Lutheran Services
Licensee Address: 4100 Pier N. Blvd Ste. A
Flint, MI 48504-1487
Licensee Telephone #: (989) 262-7386
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Kathleen Schultz/Steven Zwart
Name of Facility: Wellspring Lutheran Services Oak Park
Facility Address: 25900 Greenfield Suit 401
Oak Park, MI 48237
Facility Telephone #: (248) 968-0100
Original Issuance Date: 08/01/1992
Service Types: CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s):04/01/2019, 04/02/2019, 04/04/2019 & 04/05/2019

No. of licensed foster homes 35 3

Independent Living Youth NA

Others (please identify person interviewed by role)

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are unrelated
to the staff person.
One of eight new employee records reviewed did not show
documentation of three references for the employee, identified
as an Intern.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all necessary
collateral contacts.
One of seven special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation of a thorough evaluation. All parties who may
have had information pertaining to the allegations were not
interviewed.
R400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons interviewed,
and names of the interviewers. If children are interviewed, their
last names shall not be included in the report.
In one of seven special evaluations reviewed the report did not
include the location where all persons were interviewed.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2016.
R 400.12404 Placement.
(3) An agency's placement of a child in a foster home shall be
consistent with the placement specifications for the home.
4

In one of six open foster home records reviewed, the record
showed the home was licensed as a foster family foster group
home for five children. However, six children were placed in
the home from 12/5/18 until 2/28/19, when one child was
returned home.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent, then the reason why
return is not possible.
One of six open child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (b) related to the child’s replacement as
required by the rule.
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R 400.12404(4).
One of six open child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (d) related to the child’s replacement, as
required by the rule.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child's age,
appropriate to the child's capacity to understand, which includes
an explanation to all relevant parties as to why the change is
necessary.
One of six open child records, and four of four closed child
records reviewed did not show documentation of the child’s
preparation for the change as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer guardian
ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the change in
placement.
5

(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417.
(j) Supervisory approval before the change.
One of six open child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (f)-(g) related to one of the child’s
replacements, as required by the rule.
(f) is a Repeat Violation- Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
(g) is a Repeat Violation- Renewal 2017.
(j) is a Repeat Violation- Interim 2016.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement.
(a)A summary of the services provide during care up to the time
of the change in placement and the needs that remain to be
met.
(b)Provision for continuing services.
Three of four closed child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) and (b) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of
the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
6

One of six open child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (c)-(h) as required by the rule related to the
child’s replacement.
Repeat Violations- Interim 2018, Renewal 2017.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two of fifteen updated services plans reviewed were one and
six days late respectively.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
 In two of three enrolled records reviewed, the foster
home application was not uploaded.
 In three of three closed foster home records reviewed all
required documents were not uploaded. Two records did
not show MISCAWIS documentation of the foster home
child placement list. The other did not show
documentation upload of the transfer 3706 for the foster
home.
 Of six open foster home records, where a special
evaluation was completed, various records did not show
consistent uploads of the 259s.
 In one of four closed child records reviewed the
MISACWIS record did not show uploads of all FTM-1105
forms.
 In two of six open foster child records reviewed the
MISCAWIS record did not show upload of one child’s
7/4/18-10/1/18 signed updated service plan; and the
7

other record did not show upload of the child’s signed
PATPA for 6/26/18-9/23/18.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016-
cited under contract.
ISEP 6.18 Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Timeliness (Commitment
54).
Relative foster parents must be licensed within 180 days of the
date of placement.
One of four unlicensed relative applicant records reviewed,
showed the relative was not licensed with 180 days of the
relative’s 11/7/17 application date. The record indicated the
home was compliance with all licensing rules by 1/29/18 and
3/29/18 respectively. The home was not licensed until 7/30/18.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2018.
ISEP 6.30 Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66).
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on
the worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and approve
each service plan. The plan can be approved only after the
supervisor has a face-to-face meeting with the worker, which
can be the monthly meeting.
Two of fifteen updated service plans reviewed did not show
documentation of a face-to-face meeting as required by the
standard. A supervisory meeting either occurred the month
prior or the month after the supervisory approval of the service
plan.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
ISEP 6.33 Assessments and Service Plans Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Of fifteen service plans reviewed three did not show
compliance:
8

 Two did not show documentation of the youth’s
signature.
 One did not show documentation of the birth parent’s
signature.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, and
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors) and
provided to the foster care provider.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation that the medical passport was updated quarterly.
Two of these did not show clear documentation the medical
passport was provided to each required foster parent or relative.
Repeat Violations- Renewal 2017, Interim 2016- cited under
policy.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
Policy FOM 722- Family Team Meetings
6B
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
-Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
-Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption:
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change. Planned and unplanned
placement changes include reunification, placement in a
9

residential setting, step-down from a residential or hospital
setting, return from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
Semi- Annual Transitional Meeting:
Within 30 calendar days after the youth’s 14th birthday and
every six months thereafter.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Two of six open child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of an FTM for
the child’s 9/20/18 and 3/9/19 replacement.
This same record did not show documentation of a timely
semi-annual transitional meeting due by November 2018.
The semi-transitional meeting was completed 1/18/19.
 A second record did not show documentation of an FTM
for the child’s 8/31/18-11/28/18 USP. Additionally, the
FTM for this child’s previous USP 6/2/18-8/30/18 was not
within the timeframe as required by the rule. A FTM was
completed on 6/18/18.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
Policy FOM 722- Caseworker Contact
6-H
Timely entry of Caseworker contacts
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within
five business days of the contact. This includes the following:
 Any face-to-face contacts with children, parents, or
caregivers made by any of the following:
--Foster care worker.
 Parent/child face-to-face contacts.
 Sibling/child face-to-face contacts
10

All other social work contacts must be entered prior to the report
period end date on the applicable case service plan.
Three of six open child records reviewed showed consistently
late social work contacts entries, with various contacts over
thirty days.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2018, Interim 2016.
Policy FOM 722- Unannounced home visit
6H
The caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the
placement every quarter. This unannounced visit must be noted
in the social work contacts of the case service plan.
Three of six open child records reviewed did not show
documentation of compliance:
 One child’s record did not show documentation of an
unannounced home visit for the quarterly period 9/24/18-
12/21/18.
 A second child’s record did not show documentation of
an unannounced home visit for the quarterly period
7/4/18-10/1/18.
 A third child’s record did not show documentation of an
unannounced home visit for the quarterly period 6/2/18-
8/30/18 or 8/31/18-11/28/18.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
Policy FOM 722- Foster Care- Updated Service Plan.
9
Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report.
Three of fifteen updated service plans reviewed were late by:
 Two days.
 Twenty-seven days.
 Forty-four days.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
FOM 722-09C Foster Care Action Summary.
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a case.
The foster care action summary is generated from SWSS FAJ.
The DHS worker must complete the DHS-69, Action Summary
11

(RFF 69) in SWSS. Child placing agencies will continue to use
the DHS-69, Action Summary template. This form also serves
as notice to the courts of changes in placements, parent's living
situation and the FC worker/agency, as identifying information is
indicated. The FC/JJ action summary meets licensing
requirements for replacement documentation (See FOM 722-
03) and in most cases, agency transfer and case closing
summary (see below). The FC/JJ action summary must also be
used for foster care transfer to adoption.
Which Cases/ When
All foster care cases where there is:
1. Replacement.
2. Termination from foster care placement.
 One of six open child records reviewed did not show
documentation of a DHS-69 for the child’s replacement
on 9/20/18.
 Four of four closed child records reviewed did not show
documentation of a DHS-69 for the child’s termination
from foster care.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2016 cite under FOM 913-4
12

CI 16-182a Communication Issuance.
Security Awareness Training for Fingerprint Base Criminal
History Requirements.
Security Awareness Training (SAT) is required for authorized
personnel who have been granted access to fingerprint-based
Criminal History Record Information (CHRI). This training
provides information on what fingerprint based CHRI is, who
has access, how to ensure this information remains secure both
physically an electronically, and how you can use this
information appropriately.
Security Awareness Training is required to be completed no
later than Tuesday February 10, 2017 for all non-contracted and
governmental CPA employees, subcontractors, subcontractor’s
employees or volunteers who are authorized to have access to
fingerprint-based CHRI.
All non-contracted and governmental CPA employees,
subcontractors, subcontractor’s employees or volunteers who
are authorized to have access to fingerprint-based CHRI must
successfully complete SAT within six months of appointment to
a position with CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
One of seven current employees listed as having access to
CHRI did not show documentation the employee completed the
required annual recertification training by the 12/28/18 due date.
It was completed on 3/11/19.
One of two employees who left the agency did not show
documentation the employee completed the required
recertification training by the 1/9/19 due date. The respective
employee left the agency 1/31/19.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R400.12208 Job description
 The agency was apprised a job description, as described by the rule shall
exist for each position held, including Interns.
R400.1212(3)(a) Personnel records
 The employee’s written evaluation shall clearly and accurately document the
time period the evaluation was completed for and the date of completion.
13

R400.12327(5)(e) Special evaluation.
 The agency was apprised its finding of facts, based on evidence shall be
clearly and consistently described in the analyst section of the special
evaluation report.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12306(3) & (4) Application request.
 The agency was advised regularly uploading into MISCAWIS its agency
application request form and annual inspection letter it sends foster parents,
may aid it in demonstrating ongoing compliance to each aspect of the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The first incident related to a 9/12/18 allegation that the foster father pushed the two
foster boys against a dresser after he woke up and found the boys trying to get their
tablets from the foster parents’ bedroom. A corrective action plan was completed
with the foster parents, which consisted of the foster parents completing a licensing
rules refresher course, and the licensing worker reviewing the behavior management
rules with the foster parents at quarterly home visits.
The agency adhered to departmental timeframes. It adhered to all applicable rules
except R400.1327(5)(d), which was cited earlier in this report. The agency’s actions
in this matter appeared to have been appropriate.
The second incident related to a 12/4/18 allegation that the foster mother pulled one
foster daughter’s hair after that foster daughter refused to hit another foster daughter
back after being instructed to do so by the foster mother. The foster home was
found in violation of the behavior management rules. A corrective action plan was
completed with the foster parents, which consisted of the foster parent attending a
trauma-based behavioral management training, and the foster parents meeting with
the licensing worker to review the agency’s discipline policy and the behavior
management rules.
The agency adhered to departmental timeframes. It was not clearly documented
how the agency arrived at its inappropriate discipline conclusion. The agency
received technical assistance related to R400.12327(e).
14

The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. This corrective action plan related to the
agency’s 2018 Interim inspection where the agency received:
 One rule citation related to personnel records.
 Three rule citations related to licensing records.
 Three rule category citations related to foster care service rules.
 Four ISEP rule violations.
 Thirteen Departmental Policy violations.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan. It made significant
improvements related to rule/standard compliances pertaining to that corrective action
plan. It was not totally successful with that corrective plan as indicated by the repeat
violations documented in this report.
It is noted, the agency experienced a number of staffing changes since last the
inspection. There is a new foster care/licensing program manager, foster care
supervisor and office secretary. The prior program manager was promoted to division
director/chief administrator. Two of the agency’s four foster care workers and one of
their three licensing workers are new. The agency is adjusting to these changes and
have been working diligently to train all staff and to improve it rule compliance standing.
It also noted, the agency is requesting approval to provide independent living services.
Policies and procedures for this service category were previously submitted; and
recommended amendments to those policies have been submitted.
DCWL ANALYST CONCERNS ADDRESSED:
Safety Alert #1: No concerns.
Safety Alert #2: No Concerns
Safety Alert # 3:
Concern:
The foster parent requested assistance from the foster care worker to obtain a copy of
the educational assessment that was completed through Detroit Public School. The
foster care worker has not assisted. The assessment was completed in February 2019.
Resolution:
Case documentation showed that the foster care worker was assisting the relative foster
parent in obtaining a special education assessment for the child via the Detroit Public
School system. MISAWCIS documentation indicated an assessment took place
2/27/19. The agency reported the foster parent, who has contact with the school reports
the full assessment had not been completed. The agency is following up with the
relative foster parent and the school.
Concern:
15

The foster parent is concerned the child might have ADHD. The child might need a
referral for Infant Mental Health Services.
Resolution:
The agency received assignment of this case 7/30/18. The agency was unaware of the
relative foster parent’s concern of the child possibly being ADHD. This nor a request for
a Mental Health Service were reported by the relative foster parent. The agency will
address these concerns with the relative foster parent at the next foster home visit.
Concern:
The child did not receive an Early On assessment despite one being requested by the
foster parent.
Resolution:
The agency reported the child was referred for Early On Services. MISACWIS
case documentation showed the child (now age three) was referred for Early On
Services three times. The child was originally referred on 5/11/17 while under the care
and direct supervision of Oakland County DHHS. DHHS referred the child again on
10/15/18. Past social work contacts for 7/26/17 and 9/21/17 indicated the child was
participating in Early-On Services. The latter contact indicated the relative foster parent
reported Early On visited with the child four times. Then that these services were no
longer needed. Early On Service referral paper work was completed for the child again
on 12/3/18, but due to the child’s age, she was then referred for assessment via the
Detroit Public school system.
Concern:
The foster parent has not participated in at least one Family Team Meeting.
Resolution:
MISACWIS case documentation showed the agency completed two FTMs (11/16/18
and 2/15/19) since receipt of the child’s case on 7/30/18. MISACWIS social work
contact showed the 11/16/18 FTM took place in the relative foster parent’s home. A
DHS -1105 FTM form was completed, the relative foster parent did not sign it.
Safety Alert #4:
Concern:
The child that is placed in the home requires a wheel chair. The home does not have a
a wheelchair ramp. The child is currently in a safety plan with a relative. The home
does not have wheelchair ramp.
Resolution:
The agency reported the child was previously placed in this relative’s home and
returned to this placement after special investigation concerns surfaced pertaining to the
relative the child was placed with. A portable wooden ramp is currently being used while
the relative works with MORC to secure a permanent ramp.
16

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
April 15, 2019
______________________________________
Lonia Perry Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 18, 2019
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
17
